questiontext.text:
David is fighting Goliath. If David's 1.06 m slingshot is accelerated for 0.8 s at 13 rad/s2, what will be the initial linear velocity of the projected stone as it leaves the slingshot?




(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=11:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

(Question ID #1)

generalfeedback.text:
First of all we need to calculate the stone's angular velocity at the moment it leaves the slingshot, using one of the equations from the previous question:

$$\small\omega=\alpha\cdot t=13\time0.8=10.4$$ rad/s.


Next, we need to convert this angular velocity into linear velocity using the relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$, where $$V$$ is linear velocity in m/s, $$r$$ is radius in m, and $$\small\omega$$ is angular velocity, in rad/s.


Applying this equation to this question gives,

$$V=1.06\times10.4=11$$ m/s.


This is equivalent to 40 km/h!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

hint.text:
HINT

Calculate the stone's angular velocity, and then convert this to linear velocity.

questiontext.text:
David is fighting Goliath. If David's 1.08 m slingshot is accelerated for 1 s at 19 rad/s2, what will be the initial linear velocity of the projected stone as it leaves the slingshot?




(Please give your answer correct to 1.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=20.5:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again} m/s

(Question ID #100)

generalfeedback.text:
First of all we need to calculate the stone's angular velocity at the moment it leaves the slingshot, using one of the equations from the previous question:

$$\small\omega=\alpha\cdot t=19\time1=19$$ rad/s.


Next, we need to convert this angular velocity into linear velocity using the relationship $$V=r\cdot \omega$$, where $$V$$ is linear velocity in m/s, $$r$$ is radius in m, and $$\small\omega$$ is angular velocity, in rad/s.


Applying this equation to this question gives,

$$V=1.08\times19=20.5$$ m/s.


This is equivalent to 74 km/h!
